> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Pardeep Duggal" <psduggal@h...> wrote:
> >
> > Hi,
> >   Could someone tell me how to test methods that do not return any
> value. For example, the loadFromDatabase() or similar methods that do
> not return any value but in turn loads internally a vector or a Hash
> table with some specific data. and the data it loads is accesible
> thru the get methods. by calling the get methods and seeing if it
> does not return me null value is one option, but this does not tell
> me whether the correct data has been loaded.

Why not just call the get methods and assert that the data are correct?

    myfoo.load();
    assertEquals("one", myfoo.get(1));
    assertEquals("three", myfoo.get(3));
    assertEquals("five", myfoo.get(5));
    assertEquals(3, myfoo.size());

myfoo.size() might be a package-protected method that's not part of
the public interface, but only for testing.

> >   also how do we test database related methods which involve
> updating the database??

Execute the method and then access the database directly to ensure
that the change really happened.

Two methods I've used to minimize the intrusiveness of this:

    1. Start a transaction. Call the update method. Run a query to
    verify that the update was correct. Rollback the transaction.

    2. Create a temporary table from the original table. (In PostgreSQL,
    "SELECT * INTO TEMP foo FROM foo". This will hide the original foo
    for your connection only.) Call the update method. Run a query to
    verify that the update was correct. Close the connection, which will
    remove the temporary table.
